bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, August 25, 1928

div1.p: Carter is having difficulty tracking down medical references. She notes that she is writing this letter on Henry Rose Carter's birthday and that, had he lived, he could have told her the source of every reference she seeks.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, August 25, 1928
div1.opener:
Report-Russell
(weekly)
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
August 25, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
The bibliographic work is still being pushed to the limit. In-
deed, I accidentally went beyond it, from a physical standpoint, this
week and had to work at home on dry toast and water--enough for mental
pabulum, but not enough for work plus the trip to the Library. Thanks
to Colonel Ashburn's kindness in letting me take books home, however,
I've been able to clear up quite a lot of work here just as well as
if I had been at the Library with Miss Brown. Miss Brown is indefati-
gable, enthusiastic and most efficient. We expect to work together at the
Library to-morrow (Sunday). Indeed, Miss Brown has come to my apart-
ment every day I've been away, in order that we might check up our
work and also to bring me additional material. She has then gone
back to the Library to work for us at night.

Owing to insufficient data, the task of finding the places of
publication of some of the medical references has proven much harder
than I had anticipated. This despite the wonderful facilities of the
Library of the Surgeon General and the interest and co-operation of
that part of its staff specially trained in reference work. I have
also, as I previously wrote you, written to, and consulted with, a
number of men who should be able to help me verify specific references,
and am continuing to do so.

Of course, the need for getting the book out as soon as possi-
ble with the resultant limit as to the amount of time that we are
justified in spending on the bibliographic work is why we have been
pushing it so vigorously and for such long hours. Even at that, how-
ever, there will remain references impossible of verification without
a more lengthy search than is possible under the circumstances. Dr.
-2-
Dr.
Frost told me it was inevitable, in an unfinished work, published
posthumously, but that some of the references remain unverified. I
hope, however, that some more can be worked up in the interval be-
tween the time of the completion of the final editing of the MSS
and the reading of the galley proof. Indeed, I think that nearly
all could be verified with time--the thing we most lack! It would
take a lot of time, however, and much research as whatever references
remain unverified will do so in spite of having been worked over from
many angles and by many people.

Had Father lived, he could have cleared up all remaining re-
ferences as fast as he could have dictated them to me, for, as I know
you remember, he always had an exact remembrance[unclear] of the source of
his references including that from periodicals, letters and verbal communications. Even as it is, however, I feel that he would approve
of what has been done. To-day is his birthday.
div1.closer:
With best remembrances, I remain
Verytruly yours, (Signed) Laura A. Carter, Dr. Frederick F. Russell.
Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
